description.narrative: Indicators as in AWP 2016 - Households and communities have more secure livelihood asset base (5 point rating) disaggregated by gender - Increase in agricultural and other sources of income - Number of financial transactions per Self Help Group increase - Volume of targeted locally produced commodities that are processed/value added and marketed by smallholder farmers increase -Percentage of households with a rating of 4 on scale: Secure access to livelihood assets, increased by at least 20%. -50% of targeted smallholder farmers (by gender) have increased their agricultural income by at least 25%. -At least 50% of female headed households in each Self Help Group complete at least two financial transactions -At least 25% of targeted locally produced commodities in the three districts have value added and marketed by smallholder farmers - Relevant climate risk information disseminated to stakeholders - Climate information routinely and effectively used in making climate sensitive decisions -70% of smallholder farmers in the project area have access to localised climate forecasts - Climate information being routinely and effectively used by at least 50% of smallholder farmers (by gender) to make climate sensitive decisions. - Effective selection and implementation of adaptation measures - Delivery rate

comment.narrative:
Baseline data as described in AWP 2016
Output 1 Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. Baseline: - Households in project area have poor access (rating 2) to livelihood assets - Baseline agricultural income per household. Buhera $444/year, Chimanimani $864/year and Chiredzi $456 /year. - Number of existing financial self help groups and baseline financial transactions. Buhera 18,3%, Chimanimani 26,7% and Chiredzi 15,1%. - Three (3) short value chains to be targeted (Buhera: Goat, cattle, sorghum, honey. Chimanimani: Potato, goats, honey, beans, pepper and Chiredzi: Sorghum, pearl millet, cattle and goats). The baseline volume of products marketed to be determined.
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas Baseline - Smallholder farmers in target districts do not have access to regular localised climate forecasts and protocols for effective use in risk management (Buhera 71,7%, Chimanimani 76,4% and Chiredzi 65,3%) - Climate information not routinely used by stakeholders in the targeted districts
Output 3: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation Baseline: - Adaptation measures that work well in the targeted areas not clearly established
Output 4: Project management
No output targets for 2019 due to project closure. The terminal evaluation and final board meeting is expected before end of March.

Terminal evaluation rated the project successful. Overall, the project has delivered satisfactorily against the expected targets in a complex and challenging context – both in terms of the macro-economic environment and the climate induced shocks and stressors that have hit targeted areas in the projects lifetime.

Output 1: Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area End of project target • (Cumulatively 9,800 households) being 2,000 households in Buhera, 3,500 (Chimanimani) and 4,300 (Chiredzi) increasing livelihood asset base from the implemented strategic integrated micro-watershed CCA investments implemented . • Cumulatively 1800 female headed households in each targeted micro-watershed have improved access to financial services and financial transactions per Self Help Group increase by 25% over the baseline • Cumulatively 600 households in each of the three targeted value chains have improved market literacy and linkages with markets and service providers, and their volume of marketed products increase by at least 20% over the baseline. • Agricultural and income from other sources among at least 25% of the farmers participating in the project increase by at least 20% over the baseline.
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas End of project target • (4,400 households) being 800 households in Buhera, 1800 (Chimanimani) and 1800 (Chiredzi) receiving relevant climate risk information. • 25% of targeted farmers routinely and effectively using climate information to make climate sensitive decisions. • Stakeholders have capacity to reach at least 25% of targeted beneficiaries with improved climate services for climate risk management

The Terminal Evaluation started in December 2018 and will continue into January 2019, when the final board meeting will be held.
Output 1: By November 2018, overall project reach remained at 8 862hh (3590 M and 5272 F) across the three districts during the month as consolidation of interventions implemented across the districts continued. Financial access remained at 3287hhs (537M, 2750F) in 254 VSLA groups across the districts of Buhera, Chimanimani and Chiredzi. Adaptive capacity investments remained at 5389hh (2466 M, 2923 F) whilst market linkages remained at 2053hh (1,016M, 1037F).
In terms of reduced vulnerability, the 2018 annual target focused on that 2000 hh (Buhera), 3,750 (Chimanimani) and 4,350 (Chiredzi) had a livelihood asset rating of 4 on scale for cumulative 20% of beneficiaries. In the Q3 of 2018 it was reported that there was an increase in households with secure access to livelihood assets (rating 4) to 15.2% from a baseline value of 3.2% according to the impact survey conducted in June 2018. The majority of the households (57.5%) have moved to moderate access (rating 3). In Buhera District households with secure access (rating 4) increased to 25% from 3.4% at baseline, Chimanimani District (8.0% from 4% at baseline), and Chiredzi District (13% from 2.1% at baseline).
In terms of value chain development and market linkages, cumulatively the project reached 2053hh (1,016M, 1037F) across the project sites with Buhera, 711 hhs (388 M, 323 F), Chimanimani, 350 hhs (201 M, 149 F) and Chiredzi, 940 (395M, 545F). Interventions aimed at increasing incomes for the community start from adaptive investments, financial access support and market linkages. Various value chains have been supported and have increased farmers’ income, incl.: Michigan Pea beans, sugar beans, honey, livestock, leafy vegetables. Overall household income increased for 32% of farmers targeted by the project. In Buhera District farmers increased their income to an average of $1 321/year for 38.6% of farmers from $444/year at baseline representing a 198 percent increase in income. In Chimaninani District average household income increased to $994/year for 30.4%% of farmers from $864/year at baseline representing a 15 percent increase in income. In Chiredzi District average household income increased to $1 072/year for 27% of farmers from $456/year at baseline which is a 135 percent increase in income.
There was also an increase in the number of beneficiaries with financial access to 3247 people (537M, 2710F) across the three districts for 250 Village Savings and Lending. Buhera, increased to 1127 (152 M, 975 F) in 86 groups, Chimanimani increased to 416 (89M, 327 F) in 27 groups, and Chiredzi remained at 1704 hhs (1408F, 296M) in 137 groups. Chimanimani is working with Nyanyadzi irrigation scheme, whose main livelihood has been supported by the project, to increase VSLA groups.
Overall, satisfactory results have been achieved under this output and initial findings from the terminal evaluation point to a high likelihood of communities being able to sustain results.
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas
The Q3 report of 2018 established that 40% of targeted farmers routinely and effectively using climate information to make climate sensitive decisions in agriculture and disaster risk management. It also highlighted that all actors in the climate information value chain have capacity to continue providing tailored climate products for smallholder farmers and disaster risk management. About 58.4% of farmers surveyed received weather and seasonal climate outlooks through the radio (Buhera 76%, Chimanimani 73.8% and Chiredzi 25.5%). In Chiredzi District social media was used to disseminate medium range and seasonal rainfall outlook information since most parts of the district have limited to no radio coverage. The project supported the Meteorological Services Department to produce localised 7-day rainfall outlooks for the project areas and the rest of the country. Farmers across the project sites received seasonal forecast for 2016/17 season. Nature of decisions made using the received information include when to plant, crops to plant and area to plant
However, a lot more capacity building focusing on human resources is required for the Meteorological Services Department to develop and generate tailored weather and climate products for smallholder farmers. Also, while the ICT based climate information dissemination system was developed & installed at MSD and Agritex, full operationalization of the climate information dissemination platform is underway. The expected results under this output have only been partially reached; largely due to capacity challenges in the MSD and Agritex; and the discussion on further capacity building and sustainability will be taken up as part of the final board meeting and has been incorporated in fundraising for possible successor projects.
